items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely between approximately 12:30 and 2pm this afternoon, Friday 10th October.  This is due to tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth and creating a natural tide locking effect. This will restrict the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.   We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm today, Friday 10th October.

Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds.  There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60mAOD at 17:30 on 10/10/2025.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 17 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next five days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 10/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: This flood alert is no longer in force as tides are now falling and no longer pose a risk of flooding.

Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The previous tide of concern overnight has now passed, the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide this afternoon.

items.description: The Essex coast from St Peters Flat to and including Shoeburyness and the Crouch and Roach estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Crouch, River Roach, North Sea

items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

High spring tides may lead to flooding this evening. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, however property flooding is not expected.

The highest tide level is expected at the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point, including Porlock Weir, at 9:15 PM on 09/10/2025. Flooding is possible an hour and a half either side of this time.

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley Point of 6.37 mAODN at 9:15 PM on 09/10/2025, with Northerly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)
 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Further flood alerts may be issued for this current sequence of high Spring tides.

This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 10/10/2025, or as the situation changes.
